Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Inferring High Latitude Convection Patterns Using SuperDARN, DMSP and ACE
Award.AbstractNarration:
Observations of ionospheric convection from SuperDARN and DMSP along with ACE solar wind observations will be used to develop a new high-latitude convection model. The approach will be to use Data Interpolating Orthogonal Functions (DINEOFs). DINEOFs are a data-based technique that determines a limited set of basis functions and their evolution that best describes a data set. The basis functions will be used to study the interaction between polar cap convection and the solar wind. The technique allows the two ionospheric data sets to be combined and will fill gaps in the data record without using bin-averaging as is presently done. The approach is rigorous and provides error estimates. The resulting model will provide spatial and temporal characteristics of the convection for both hemispheres.

This model will be valuable to other magnetospheric and ionospheric researchers. It is from a young researcher just starting his career and will support a post-doctoral researcher at the University of Texas at Dallas. A graduate student will be supported at Virginia Tech.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the use of Data Interpolating Empirical Orthogonal Functions (DINEOFs) to analyze the record of SuperDARN measurements and use those measurements to make best estimates of values in areas not measured during any given time. 

For this project, DINEOFs required significant modification to incorporate the single line-of-sight ion velocity measurements into a system that reports the full velocity vector. The modification of DINEOFs was a full success. Testing revealed DINEOFs is capable of reconstructing vector fields with incomplete information and at nearly the same performance when operating on scalar fields. Testing also revelead a high degree of performance for data coverage values of 10% or more. This minimum data coverage is likely lower than truly required when analyzing more complex physical systems. SuperDARN data coverage is generally around 7%. While the combination of DINEOFs and SuperDARN was successful in estimating convection maps at a two minute cadence, more work is required to improve the reliability.

Several SuperDARN data improvement projects were undertaken to process all of the data with the latest calibration work. The results are currently stored at the University of Texas at Dallas.

The DINEOF analysis procedure was built on top of the Python Satellite Data Analysis Toolkit (pysat), available to the public. Pysat is a high level space science package that provies a common ground for all instruments in space science. Support for both SuperDARN and DMSP was added to this public pakage. Significant unit testing and other work was undertaken as part of this grant.

As a result of this efforts, three publications were produced, and two technologies were developed. Pysat is available to the public. The DINEOFs package has been generalized, thus it is also capable of ingesting measurements from other measurement domains. These features are expected to provide significant benefits to future integrative investigations.
